author: Special Correspondent
text:
The groundbreaking ceremony for the construction of the State’s first 800-MW supercritical thermal power plant at North Chennai was performed in Tiruvallur district on Friday.

The stage III plant is coming up within the existing NCTPS complex in the Tiruvallur district. The total project cost is Rs.6376 crore and is likely to be commissioned in August 2019.

Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited (BHEL) bagged the Rs. 2,759-crore contract for its part of the North Chennai Supercritical TPS Stage III and Chief Minister Jayalalithaa handed over the Letter of Award for the plant to Atul Sobti, BHEL CMD in January.

The BHEL component for the boiler will be manufactured in Tiruchi, the electrostatic precipitator from its Ranipet plant, the control station from the Bangalore facility and turbine and generator from Haridwar.

The supercritical power plant has better efficiency when it comes to power generation and uses less coal compared to conventional thermal plants, officials said.

Aviation clearance for the project was obtained in May 2013, environmental clearance in January 2016 and the Memorandum of Understanding for coal for 2.51 MPTA was signed with MMTC in May 2015.

The techno-commercial bid for the balance of plant package including all civil works was opened in January and is under evaluation.

Sambath Kumar, director (projects), Tangedco; A.K. Mukhopadhyay, general manager (in-charge), BHEL; Santosh Nair, GM (Project V), BHEL and other senior officials of Tangedco and BHEL were present on the occasion, said a release.

The plant uses less coal compared to conventional thermal plants
title: Work begins on TN’s first supercritical thermal plant
